Award.AwardTitle: IRES: Changing Landscapes, Biodiversity, and Ecosystem Function in an African Global Biodiversity Hotspot in Swaziland
Award.AbstractNarration:
This International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) project will engage U.S. undergraduate students in field-based ecology and conservation research in the southern Africa country of Swaziland. The project will use mentoring, teamwork and innovative research to train students to address some of the planet's most pressing conservation issues. Students will work with American and African scientists to study the integration of human livelihoods and needs for agricultural production with the need to maintain the diverse and vigorous ecosystems that allow human communities to thrive. Working internationally in Swaziland, students will first gain an understanding of regional cultures, natural history, ecological theory and research techniques. Students will then spend their summer conducting independent research projects. Over the course of the project student research projects will examine how recently converted agricultural lands may alter wildlife communities and the health of entire ecosystems. As global biodiversity continues to decline and agricultural landscapes increase, this project will help us understand how to maintain biodiversity, healthy ecosystems, and human livelihoods. Additionally, the program will produce a new generation of scientists who will spread their newly found knowledge to local and global audiences and be well prepared to face our planet's growing conservation challenges.

Global conservation efforts must embrace agricultural landscapes, because agriculture has and will continue to play a dominant role in shaping land-use practices. Nonetheless, there is only a limited understanding of how agricultural landscapes alter biodiversity and ecosystems? ability to provide resources for humans (ecosystem services). One major hypothesis for balancing agricultural production with biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is the habitat heterogeneity hypothesis. Swazi and American scientists will work with students to understand the role of heterogeneity on faunal biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. One cohort of students will relate variation in the distribution of faunal communities to patterns in landscape heterogeneity. A second cohort of students will test the mechanisms that drive faunal community changes in agriculturally dominated landscapes. A final cohort of students will examine how landscape heterogeneity and faunal communities influence ecosystem functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global conservation efforts for biodiversity and ecosystem functioning must embrace agricultural landscapes, because agriculture has and will continue to play a dominant role in shaping land-use practices and human livelihoods. Nonetheless, there is only a limited understanding of how agricultural landscapes alter biodiversity. One major hypothesis for balancing agricultural production with biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is the habitat heterogeneity hypothesis. While training the next generation of field ecologist student led research found support for the heterogeneity hypothesis was limited and should not be broadly applied.

 

For his program, fifteen students from eight U.S. University?s received technical training in ecological field research, scientific communication, writing, statistics, landscape ecology and biodiversity. They participated in a 3-week study abroad program in Swaziland at the University of Florida?s Savanna Research Center. In Swaziland they conducted 6 weeks of independent research. American student worked with students from the University of Swaziland and were mentored by faculty and researchers from the University of Swaziland, the University of Cape Town and the Organization for Tropical Studies. Student driven research measuring biodiversity found that heterogeneous landscapes can increased the biodiversity of some taxonomic groups while reducing the biodiversity of others. Their research examining animals? movements suggested that small birds have limited dispersal abilities across agriculture field and that large savanna trees appear to have lost their interactions with the animals that disperse them. Finally, students found that heterogenous agriculture and areas with elevated shrub cover both eroded the ecological services that animals provide to savannas and people.

 

We created a multicultural research teams of students that were positive, supportive, passionate and highly efficient and effective. Student research led to 4 honors thesis, 1 master thesis, publication of 5 peer-reviewed manuscripts (with more on the way) and over 15 presentations at scientific meetings. We now have empirical evidence to suggest that the heterogeneity hypothesis cannot be broadly applied across taxonomic groups. These finding will guide the management of agricultural landscape and guide future research efforts to facilitate landscapes that can be used by humans and wildlife alike.
